newsitem.title: GERMANY: German minister denies army short on readiness.
newsitem.headline: German minister denies army short on readiness.

text.p: Defence Minister Volker Ruehe on Wednesday denied that cuts in defence spending had reduced the combat-readiness of Germany's armed forces to an unacceptable level.
Ruehe told parliament in a budget debate that defence spending was lower now than it was in 1991. But he said the standards of readiness required had also come down since the end of the Cold War.

"Take a look -- the Russians are no longer standing at the Elbe (river in east Germany)," he said. "We no longer have to mobilise our army within 24 hours or have the entire armed forces ready for combat within seven days.
"Now we would get between one and two years' advance warning of a major conflict."

Opposition Social Democrat defence spokesman Walter Kolbow accused Ruehe of presiding over a gradual decay of the armed forces. "We have reached a worrying state of affairs. The army has only limited combat-readiness," he said.

Ruehe said in his speech the government preferred to save on major capital investment rather than cut corners in training, soldiers' personal equipment or the German contribution to the peace implementation force in Bosnia.
But he did not say which major purchases, if any, he planned to postpone or scrap.

Last weekend he said he expected the parliament to make a "positive decision" early next year on buying Eurofighter jets, being built by British Aerospace, Germany's Daimler-Benz Aerospace, Alenia of Italy and Casa of Spain.

German and French defence planners are compiling a report, ahead of a meeting next month between Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Jacques Chirac, on the future of a range of joint procurement projects including helicopters and satellites.
